questions.question: Question 1: What is the protein coat covering the nucleic acid in a virion known as?
questions.explanation:
The protein coat covering the nucleic acid in a virion is called capsid. The parts of a virus include: • Nucleocapsid- capsid with enclosed nucleic acid • Tegument- proteinaceous structure present between the envelope and capsid. • Envelope- lipid-containing membrane that surrounds some virus particles. It is acquired during 
viral maturation by a budding process through a cellular membrane. • Peplomers- virus-encoded glycoproteins, on the outer surface of the envelope as projections. Characteristics of viruses: • Do not have a cellular organization • Have either DNA or RNA but never both • Obligate intracellular parasites • Lack enzymes necessary for protein and nucleic acid synthesis • Filterable • Cannot be grown on artificial media • Unaffected by antibiotics. Note : Martinus beijerinck proposed the theory of contagium vivum fluidum (living infectious 
fluid) while studying the cause of mosaic disease of tobacco plant. He is known as the father of 
virology. 342

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following is an enveloped virus?
questions.explanation:
Hepatitis C virus is an enveloped virus. It has a linear, single-stranded RNA genome, enclosed within a core and surrounded by an 
envelope.

questions.question:
Question 5: A patient in the ICU requires fresh frozen plasma (FFP). The FFP that arrives from the blood 
bank is labeled as Solvent/Detergent plasma, which destroys lipid-enveloped viruses. Which 
of the following viral infections is the patient still susceptible to?
questions.explanation:
The patient is still susceptible to hepatitis A infection. It is a non-enveloped virus, and hence it’s 
not affected by SD plasma. 343 
Sold by @itachibot Solvent/Detergent plasma (SD plasma) is a form of blood plasma made from plasma collected 
from many people which is then processed with solvents in an attempt to remove viruses. Only the viruses with an envelope are susceptible to SD plasma destruction. Hepatitis B, C, and 
Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) are enveloped.

questions.question: Question 6: In which of the following viruses is a segmented genome found?
questions.explanation:
Segmented genome is found in orthomyxovirus. Segmentation of viral genomes allows for the exchange of intact genes between related viruses 
during coinfection. This recombination is known as reassortment. There is a rearrangement and 
joining of nucleic acid sequences to form a unique chimeric genome. The new genome is usually 
less fit than the parent viruses, but occasionally, it results in an evolved virus with increased 
fitness. Examples of segmented viruses (ARBO): • Arenavirus (2 segments) • Rotavirus (11 segments) • Bunyavirus (3 segments) • Orthomyxovirus (8 segments) The image below shows the segmented genome seen in the influenza virus (Orthomyxoviridae)

questions.question:
Question 8: An epidemic involving an ss-RNA virus with 3'-5' RNA has broken out in West Africa. Which 
of the following enzymes do such viruses use in genome replication?
questions.explanation:
An ss-RNA with a 3'-5' strand is a negative-stranded RNA. These viruses use RNA replicase 
or RNA-dependent RNA polymerase during genome replication. In positive-stranded RNA viruses, the viral RNA itself acts as mRNA. In negative-stranded RNA viruses, the polarity is opposite that of mRNA. So the genome requires 
RNA-dependent RNA polymerase to synthesize their mRNA. Examples of negative-stranded RNA viruses (Mnemonic: Always bring da polymerase or fail to 
replicate): • Arenaviruses • Bunyaviruses • Deltaviruses • Paramyxoviruses • Orthomyxoviruses • Filoviruses • Rhabdoviruses

questions.question:
Question 10: An elderly diabetic man presents with a complaints of fever, cough and difficulty in breathing 
for the past 3 days. He gives a history of international travel 1’ days back. Laboratory reports 
show positive for COVID-19. What is the symmetry of the causative virus?
questions.explanation:
The patient is suffering from coronavirus disease 2’19 (COVID-19). The coronavirus implicated 
shows an enveloped helical symmetry. Properties of Coronaviridae family: • They are enveloped RNA viruses. • They contain a genome of unsegmented single-stranded and positive-sense RNA • They have helical nucleocapsid

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following statements is false regarding symmetry of viruses ?

options.a: Viral symmetry is studied by heavy metals stains.
options.b: The most efficient closed shell sub-unit arrangement is icosahedral.
options.c: Icosahedral symmetry involves 12 faces and 2’ vertices .
options.d: It is not possible for 'empty' helical particles to form

questions.explanation:
Icosahedron has 2’ faces (each an equilateral triangle) and 12 vertices. Option A: Study of viral symmetry by standard electron microscopy requires the use of heavy 
metal stains (e.g., potassium phosphotungstate) to emphasize surface structure. It is a form of 
negative staining. Option B: Symmetry observed with animal viruses is of the icosahedral pattern. It is the most 
efficient arrangement for subunits in a closed shell. Option D: A regular, periodic interaction between capsid protein and nucleic acid is required to 
maintain a stable helical symmetry. Therefore, it is not possible for empty helical particles to 
form. èiven below is Icosahedron: 347

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following viruses shows an enveloped icosahedral symmetry?
questions.explanation: Enveloped icosahedral symmetry is seen in the rubella virus.

questions.question:
Question 13: An immunologist is working on growing the influenza virus for vaccine production at the 
National Institute of Virology, Pune. Which of the following sites is used for the given 
purpose in a fertilized egg?
questions.explanation:
Allantoic cavity inoculation (1) is used for the growth and replication of the influenza virus for 
vaccine production. Embryonated eggs are used for the cultivation of viruses. 348 
Sold by @itachibot Note: Both allantoic and amniotic cavity inoculation are recommended for initial isolation of the 
influenza virus. However, it is simpler to inoculate the virus into the allantoic cavity, as compared 
to the amniotic cavity, thus allantoic inoculation is the best answer.
